poem:
**The Sparks Card**

In the twilight years, she strolls  
the aisles of fresh fruit  
and neat rows of biscuits,  
a simple joy in her step.

Yet, in the hum of convenience,  
an email, a smartphone  
stand like high gates,  
denying her the small  
sparks of everyday kindness.

She sighs,  
and reaches for tea.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Sparks fly as M&S says no to a plastic loyalty card After my grandfather’s death, my 87-year-old grandmother moved into a retirement home. She is happy there and one of the best things is the nearby Marks & Spencer food hall. However, when I tried to sign her up for a Sparks card, so she can access any discounts and deals, we were told she needed an email and a smartphone. It no longer issues". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
